FacilityName: World Class Distribution, Inc. - Palmdale Hub

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policies
World Class Distribution is committed to providing a safe environment to its employees and surrounding communities. This commitment is reflected in the safety and environmental programs that are implemented at the facility. For example, written procedures have been created for operating the ammonia refrigeration system. Only trained operators / refrigeration contractor are permitted to perform system operations. World Class Distribution has also developed a robust maintenance program to ensure the equipment is in good operating condition. All of these programs are geared towards the prevention of an accidental release at the facility. In addition, these programs incorporate emergency procedures to mitigate the effects of a release if it does occur. At such an event, emergency coordinators will assess the situation and notify outside responding agencies as necessary.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
World Class Distribution is located at 700 W. Columbia Way, Suite A, Palmdale, California. Ammonia is used in the facility's refrigeration system to provide cooling for the storage and distribution of grocery products. The system uses a maximum of 32,000 pounds of ammonia. A description of how the process operates is presented below:

Liquid ammonia in the high pressure receiver is fed to the recirculator. The recirculator pumps liquid to the evaporators. At the evaporators, air is drawn over the coils by the fans. The ammonia flowing inside the coils is partially vaporized as it absorbs heat from the product and surrounding air. The partially vaporized ammonia is returned to the recirculator, where the liquid settles at the bottom of the vessel, while the vapor rises to the top. The vapor in the vessel is pulled off by the compressors and discharged to the condensers. At the condensers, the vapor is condensed back into liquid, which then drains to the receiver to be re-used in the refrigeration cycle.

MP criteria for a reportable accident (onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place). In addition, there have been no incidents at the facility in the last five years that resulted in a release of more than the Federal Reportable Quantity (100 pounds).

Emergency Response Program
World Class Distribution has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) for the purpose of protecting employees and the surrounding community. The EAP covers procedures for: 1) evacuating and accounting for visitors and employees, 2) dealing with an ammonia release and other foreseeable emergencies that could occur onsite, 3) notifying external agencies and emergency response personnel, and 4) administering first aid measures for ammonia exposure. Employees are informed of the elements of the EAP. In the event of an ammonia release, employees will evacuate or shelter-in-place, depending on the
nature of the release, and the facility will contact the refrigeration contractor (Innovative Refrigeration System, (540) 941-1991) and the fire department (Los Angeles County Fire Department, (909) 829-4441) for assistance as necessary.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
A Process Hazard Analysis and a  Seismic Assessment have been performed on the ammonia refrigeration system, and these studies have resulted in action items to improve safety at the facility. The recommendations mainly consist of formalizing procedures, implementing practices consistent with industry standards, and performing inspections and tests to maintain the integrity of the equipment. World Class Distribution has implemented several of these action items and is moving forward with completing the remaining outstanding recommendations. In addition, the facility plans to continue providing employees with a safe work environment through continued training on current policies and procedures, and conducting audits t
o identify deficiencies and make improvements.
